snippet: The constitutional protection against double jeopardy does not ordinarily apply to criminal sentencing, the Supreme Court ruled today in a decision that removed a legal cloud from the operation of some states' ''three strikes'' sentencing laws.   ...
lead_paragraph: The constitutional protection against double jeopardy does not ordinarily apply to criminal sentencing, the Supreme Court ruled today in a decision that removed a legal cloud from the operation of some states' ''three strikes'' sentencing laws. The 5-to-4 decision, upholding a ruling by the California Supreme Court, means that a state can have more than one chance to prove that a previous conviction qualifies as a ''strike'' that counts against a defendant in calculating an enhanced sentence for a new offense.
abstract: Supreme Court, 5-4, rules constitutional protection against double jeopardy does not usually apply to criminal sentencing; decision removes legal cloud over some state 'three strikes' sentencing laws; upholds California Supreme Court ruling that state can have more than one chance to prove previous conviction counts against defendant in calculating enhanced sentence for new offense; Court refuses to hear challenge to Federal law barring Government from selling or renting 'sexually explicit material' on military property, suit brought by publisher of Penthouse magazine and others (M)

headline.main: In Sentencing Under '3 Strikes' Laws, Deciding Whether Crime Is Strike Isn't Double Jeopardy
